The buddhas, tathÄgatas, are also like this. If a person praises or disparages, they always follow wisdom and practice;
If they follow arrogance, there is no such possibility.
Good sons!
It is like sugarcane. Whether a person cuts it or does not cut it, it does not lose its sweetness.
Good sons!

The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are also like this. Whether people associate with, make offerings to, and respect them, or do not associate with, make offerings to, and respect them, they will never abandon the sweet taste of liberation.
Good sons!
It is like the earth, whose nature is stable and does not discriminate among beings.
If someone wishes to obtain its fruits and is able to plow and plant in a timely manner, and timely remove weeds, that person will harvest fruits at the right time;
If one does not plow, plant, or remove weeds, that person will never obtain its fruits.
Good sons!
The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are also like this. Like that earth, they are always still and do not discriminate among beings.
If there are beings who seek the Buddha's merits and are able to give rise to faith, make offerings, and respect [the Buddha], that person will accomplish the fruits of merit;
If one does not give rise to faith, make offerings, and be respectful, then one will not be able to obtain the fruits of merit and virtue.
Good sons!

It is like a person who, having reviled and slandered sandalwood and dragon brain incense, then applies it to the body. However, that sandalwood and dragon brain incense will never fail to emit its fragrance for this person.
Good sons!

The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are also like this. If a person reviles and slanders them, and then again draws near, makes offerings, is respectful, and practices in accordance with the teachings, then the tathÄgatas will always endow that person with complete merit and virtue.
Good sons!
It is like a bridge or a level royal road, which for all beings - of superior, middling, or inferior natures - who come and go, remains the same, and grants the pleasure of unimpeded travel.
Good sons!

The buddhas, tathÄgatas are also like this. For all beings, whether of superior, middling, or inferior natures, those who practice are equally present, without high or low, and endowed with the joy of practicing without obstruction.
Good sons!
It is like the medicinal tree king in the snow mountains called Good to See. Those who see that medicinal tree king immediately get rid of all illnesses and suffering.
Good sons!
The buddhas, tathÄgatas are also like this. Those who see beings get rid of all the suffering of afflictions.
Good sons!

This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas entering ten kinds of dharma practices and being able to know the buddhas, tathÄgatas, arhats, samyak-saá¹ƒbuddhas' characteristics corresponding to parables.
Good sons!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter ten kinds of dharma practices and are able to know the buddhas.
What are the ten?

Namely, the Buddha of habitual tendencies, the Buddha of karmic retribution, the Buddha of samÄdhi, the Buddha of vows, the Buddha of mind, the true Buddha, the same Buddha, the transformed Buddha, the Buddha of offerings, and the Buddha of images.
Good man!
What is the Buddha of habitual tendencies?
The Buddha of habitual tendencies refers to the fruits obtained through the pÄramitÄs, and the pÄramitÄs are able to accomplish those dharmas.
They arise in dependence on the pÄramitÄs, and this is called the Buddha of habitual tendencies.
Good man!
What is the Buddha of karmic retribution?
The Buddha of karmic retribution arises based on the fruits of those habitual tendencies.

That karmic retribution forms the physical body of the retributive Buddha, and it abides in dependence on sentient beings and abides in dependence on the power of the Dharma. This is called the Buddha of karmic retribution.
Good man!
What is the Buddha of samÄdhi?

The Buddha of samÄdhi refers to the power of the samÄdhi that the TathÄgata enters. Based on the power of that entered samÄdhi, without having to make any further effort, he is able to manifest hundreds of thousands of myriads of Buddhas.
Relying on the power of upholding the samÄdhi, one is able to manifest, this is called the samÄdhi Buddha.
Good sons!
What is the vow Buddha?
The vow Buddha is the vow made by bodhisattvas:
According to what kind of sentient beings, by what kind of causes and what kind of methods, manifesting various bodily forms to liberate those sentient beings,
those sentient beings in this way and that way, manifesting forms, appearances, deportment, coming and going.
According to those sentient beings who should be liberated by seeing the Buddha's body, one manifests the Buddha's body to transform those sentient beings.
This is called the vow Buddha.
Good sons!
What is the mind Buddha?
The mind Buddha is the bodhisattvas who attain mastery over the mind. These bodhisattvas rely on mastery over the mind to accomplish various dharmas according to the mind.

These bodhisattvas, according to those sentient beings who should be transformed by seeing the Buddha's body, immediately with the sovereign mind become the Buddha's body, this is called the mind Buddha.
Moreover, good sons!
There is another different meaning:
All sentient beings, with their own pure minds, can see the Buddha, know the Buddha, and believe in the Buddha. This is called the mind Buddha.
Good sons!
What is the true Buddha?

The true Buddha is far removed from all afflictions and defilements, inconceivable, spotless and pure, with various forms and colors - the thirty-two marks, eighty minor marks, and the characteristics of a great man - ultimately accomplished. The subtle and wonderful form of the Buddha can be seen. This is called the true Buddha.
Good sons!
What is the Buddha of sameness?

The Buddha of sameness shares the same resources and enjoyments as all sentient beings, eating and drinking, walking and standing, coming and going, with the same demeanor and behavior. This is called the Buddha of sameness.
Good sons!
What is the transformation Buddha?
The transformation Buddha refers to the Buddha's samÄdhi of manifesting all forms and bodies attained by the buddhas, tathÄgatas, and bodhisattvas.

Those Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, having attained mastery, with great compassion all able to manifest, transform the Buddha's physical body to deliver sentient beings, this is called the transformation Buddha.
Good sons!
What is it to make offerings to the Buddha?
Making offerings to the Buddha means that if there is a teacher or preceptor like the Buddha, one should see them as the World-Honored One.

That person, to the teacher or preceptor like the Buddha, the World-Honored One, should see them like this, make offerings and provide for them, relying on them to receive the Dharma, fulfilling the Buddha's teachings and accomplishing the Buddha's teachings, this is called making offerings to the Buddha.
Good sons!
What is the Buddha's image?

The Buddha's image means if someone else makes a Buddha image or oneself makes a Buddha image, using all offerings, respectful things, and so forth to make offerings, be respectful, revere, praise, be intimate with, and serve.
This person, in this way, relying on that form and appearance, fulfills the Buddha's teachings and accomplishes the Buddha's teachings. This is called the Buddha in form and appearance.
Good sons!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva entering ten kinds of dharma practices and being able to know the ten kinds of buddhas.
Good sons!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva entering ten kinds of dharma practices knows that the buddhas, tathÄgatas, arhats, and samyaksaá¹ƒbuddhas only rely on words to speak the Dharma.
What are the ten?

Namely, speaking of the aggregates is only words, speaking of the realms, speaking of the sense bases, speaking of sentient beings, speaking of karma, speaking of birth, speaking of aging, speaking of death, and speaking of death followed by rebirth, in order to be free from those things, speaking of nirvÄá¹‡a is also words.
Good sons!
What is meant by speaking of the aggregates is only words?
Good sons!
In the ultimate truth, there are no such form aggregates.
If there were form aggregates in the ultimate truth, abandoning those form aggregates would be annihilation, and abandoning those dharmas would be liberation.
If that were so, then in the ultimate truth there would be form and liberation with a place to go and stay;
but that is not the case, therefore it is said that the form aggregate is only words.
Good son!
Feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also like this.
Good son!
In the ultimate truth there are no consciousness aggregates.
If there were consciousness aggregates in the ultimate truth, abandoning the dharma of consciousness would be annihilation, and abandoning that dharma would be liberation.
If that were so, then in the ultimate truth there would be consciousness and liberation with a place to go and stay;
but that is not the case, therefore it is said that consciousness is only words.
Good son!
The meaning of the realms and sense bases is also like this.
Good son!
How do you say that sentient beings are only words?
Good man!
There are only conditioned things, no sentient beings.
If sentient beings truly exist, they should not be extinguished together with the aggregates.
If they were extinguished together with the aggregates, they should be like empty space;
if not, they should be the same as the five aggregates, both being conditioned.
But this is not reasonable, therefore it is said that sentient beings are only words.
Good man!
How do you say that karma is only words?
Good man!
The one who creates karma is neither existent nor non-existent.
If the one who creates karma is existent, the creator of karma is non-existent, like empty space.
Also, just as the aggregates are conditioned, the creator is also like this.
For this reason, there is no creator and no created karma, like empty space.
How can there be a creator?
Therefore, there is no one who creates karma.
Apart from the doer, how can there be karma?
Therefore, it is said that karma is only words.
Good man!
How is it said that birth is only words?
Good man!
In the ultimate truth, there is no birth.
If there were birth in the ultimate truth, birth would be eternal;
If so, birth would not be birth.
Moreover, who is it that birth gives birth to and who does birth afflict?
Therefore, it is said that birth is only words.
Good man!
How is it said that aging is only words?
Good man!
In the ultimate truth, there is no aging.
If there were aging in the ultimate truth, then there would be no one who ages but only one who is aged.
Moreover, if there is one who is aged, then it is aging in a young person.
If aging in a young person is not aging in an old person, then one who is young has no aging, and therefore there is no aging in a young person.
If apart from aging, how can it be called aging?
In this way, aging cannot age.
If it is said that aging can age, then it is aging at a young age. Therefore, aging is said to be only words.
Good man!
It is said that death is only words.
Good man!
In the ultimate truth, there is no death.
If in the ultimate truth there were death, then the dharma of death could be obtained.
If it could be obtained, then only one person would obtain it, and the rest would not die;
But since there are still those who die, therefore in the ultimate truth there is no dharma of death.
Moreover, death does not come from anywhere, and when it goes, it does not arrive anywhere. The essence of this dharma of death is empty and quiescent. Therefore, death is said to be only words.
Good man!
How is it said that after death one is reborn, and this is only words?
Good man!
In the ultimate truth, after death one is not reborn.
If in the ultimate truth death were to lead to rebirth, then death would be the same as birth, and birth would be the same as death.
If this were so, then death and birth would be a single dharma.
Moreover, it would entail two bodies:
one that is able to take rebirth, and one that has already taken rebirth.
If there is one that takes rebirth, then there must be the five aggregates taking rebirth.
Why is this?
Because apart from the five aggregates, there is no arising of that consciousness.
It is because consciousness and mind arise in dependence on the dharmas of form, feeling, perception, and mental formations;
it is because consciousness abides in dependence on the aggregates.
If apart from dependence, then that consciousness and mind do not abide for a single moment.
Just as those dharmas abide, so is rebirth like a seed producing a sprout. Therefore, it is said that death followed by rebirth is only words.
Good sons!
How is it that in order to be apart from those things, it is said that parinirvÄá¹‡a is only words?
Good sons!
In the ultimate truth, there is no such parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Nirvana is knowing that the quiescent extinction of the world is called nirvana, but it is not the world itself that is called nirvana, nor is there nirvana apart from the world.
The world is like a dream, like an illusion, neither existent nor nonexistent, nor both existent and nonexistent.
But existent dharmas are like this, neither existent nor nonexistent, nor both existent and nonexistent; this is called arising.
Neither existent nor nonexistent, nor both existent and nonexistent, this is called cessation.
The quiescent extinction of all worldly characteristics is called nirvana.
In this way, thought is like a mirage, and feeling is like a bubble.
Like that mirage and bubble, arising and ceasing are unreal. The world and nirvana are also like this. Therefore, it is said that the world and nirvana are only words.
Good man!

This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into ten kinds of dharma practices, by which one is able to know that the buddhas, tathÄgatas, arhats, perfectly enlightened ones only rely on words to expound the Dharma.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter ten kinds of dharma practices and are well able to understand the meaning of emptiness.
What are the ten?
Namely, knowing the emptiness of no self, no sentient beings, no life, no longevity, no creator, no birth, no cessation, no action, no teacher, and no superior.
Good sons!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know the emptiness of no self?
Good sons!
Emptiness is neither existent nor nonexistent.
Good sons!
If emptiness were existent, emptiness would be conditioned, and if it were really existent, it would then be permanent.
Good sons!
If emptiness were not nonexistent, emptiness would not be emptiness.
Therefore, that emptiness is neither existent nor nonexistent. This is called knowing the emptiness of no-self.
Good son!
How does one know the emptiness of no sentient beings?
Good son!
Sentient beings are neither empty nor not empty.
If sentient beings were empty, the karma of killing would not be a sin;
if sentient beings were not empty, they would be permanent.
Therefore, the TathÄgata says that sentient beings are neither permanent nor impermanent, neither conditioned nor unconditioned. This is called knowing the emptiness of sentient beings.
Good son!
How does one know the emptiness of no life?
Good son!
Emptiness means unborn and undying.
Why is it so?
Good son!
The eyes are empty, apart from self and what belongs to self.
How are the eyes empty, apart from self and what belongs to self?
Because those dharmas are unborn and unannihilated.
In the same way, the ears, nose, tongue, and body are empty and devoid of self and what belongs to self.
How are the ears, nose, and so forth empty and devoid of self and what belongs to self?
Because those dharmas are unborn and unannihilated.
This is called knowing the emptiness of the absence of life.
Good sons!
How does one know the emptiness of the absence of a living being?
Good sons!
Emptiness is not called the number of a living being.
Those aggregates, realms, and sense bases are all empty. Based on those aggregates, realms, and sense bases, there is the provisional name of a living being.
Because of the provisional name, the characteristics of its existence and non-existence cannot be spoken of.
This is called knowing the emptiness of the absence of a living being.
Good sons!
How does a bodhisattva know the emptiness of the absence of a creator?
Good sons!
If one departs from emptiness, there is no dharma called a creator.
Moreover, if emptiness can have a creator, this is impossible.
This is called knowing the emptiness of the absence of a creator.
Good sons!
How does one know the emptiness of non-arising?
Good sons!
The Dharma of emptiness does not arise. If emptiness can be produced, then it is not emptiness. Such emptiness is not emptiness;
If there was originally no emptiness, then there would be no Dharma of emptiness.
Moreover, if emptiness arises at the beginning, then it is not emptiness.
This is called knowing the emptiness of non-arising.
Good sons!
How does one know the emptiness of non-cessation?
If a Dharma arises, then it has cessation. The Dharma of emptiness does not arise, so how can there be cessation?
This is called knowing the emptiness of non-cessation.
Good sons!
How does one know the emptiness of non-action?
Good sons!

Emptiness is not created by others or by oneself. The aggregates, realms, and sense bases are all empty. The Dharma of emptiness exists based on the aggregates, realms, and sense bases. This is called knowing the emptiness of non-action.
Good sons!
How does one know the emptiness of no teacher?
Good sons!
There is not a single person who teaches the empty one to create such various things. This is called knowing the emptiness of the one without teaching.
Good son!
How does one know the emptiness of the one without superiority?
Good son!
Emptiness is without realm, apart from realm, far removed from mind, thought, and consciousness. This is called knowing the emptiness of the one without superiority.
Good son!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva entering ten kinds of dharma practices and being well able to know the meaning of emptiness.
Good son!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva entering ten kinds of dharma practices is able to know the dharmas that are the counterparts of emptiness.
What are the ten?

Namely, the dharma of ignorance, the dharma of craving, the dharma of karma, the dharma of consciousness, the dharma of grasping, the dharma of views, the dharma of doubt, the dharma of wrong grasping, the dharma of pride, and the dharma of agitation.
Good son!
These are called the ten dharmas that are the counterparts of emptiness.
Good son!
There are two kinds of abilities and four kinds of causes for ignorance.
What are the two abilities?
First, the afflictive hindrances, second, the hindrances to wisdom.
What are the four causes?
Namely, the cause of craving the desire realm, the cause of craving the form realm, the cause of craving the formless realm, and the cause of craving non-existence.
Good sons!
There are two kinds of causes for craving and four kinds of seeking.
What are the two kinds of causes?
First, the fundamental basis for existence, second, the fundamental basis for sustenance.
What are the four kinds of seeking?
First, craving for desire, second, craving for form, third, craving for the formless, fourth, craving for non-existence.
Good sons!
There is one kind of cause for the arising of karma, three kinds of characteristics, and three kinds of karmic retribution.
Good sons!
What is the one kind of cause for arising?
Namely, the mind.
What are the three kinds of characteristics?
Namely, bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
Good man!
What are the three kinds of karmic retribution?
Namely, black with black karmic retribution, white with white karmic retribution, and black-and-white with black-and-white karmic retribution.
Good man!
What is consciousness?
Namely, the six kinds:
The consciousnesses of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind - these are called the six kinds of consciousness.
This consciousness is also of three kinds.
What are the three?
One, inverted thoughts; two, non-inverted thoughts; three, no thoughts.
Good man!
What are inverted thoughts?
Namely, thoughts of the desire realm, thoughts of the form realm, thoughts of the formless realm.
What are non-inverted thoughts?
Namely, thoughts of the Hinayana nirvana.
What are no thoughts?
Namely, being apart from those two kinds of thoughts is called no thoughts.
How is one apart from those two kinds of thoughts?
Namely, because one thinks of the unsurpassed Buddhadharma.
Good man!
There are four kinds of causes of grasping:
Namely, the grasping of desire, the grasping of views, the grasping of precepts and observances, and the grasping of the self.
Good sons!
What is the grasping of views?
There are two kinds of grasping of views:
Namely, wrong knowledge and the knowledge of views.
Wrong knowledge refers to the knowledge of wrong views.

The knowledge of views refers to the arhats' mistaken views of nirvana and their mistaken pursuit of nirvana. This is called the knowledge of views - such knowledge of views is condemned by the buddhas.
Good sons!
What is doubt?
There are two kinds of doubt:
One obstructs the Mahayana, the other obstructs the correct stage.
Good sons!
What is meant by the doubt that obstructs the Mahayana?
It refers to the narrow and inferior minds of the Å›rÄvakas and others, who aspire to quickly realize the enlightenment of the lesser vehicle.
Why is this?
They think like this:
The path of the Buddha is long and far, and the immeasurable practices are difficult to accomplish.
Therefore, I should seek the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle and quickly leave all suffering.
For this reason, one turns away from the Great Vehicle. This is called the doubt that obstructs the Great Vehicle.
What is the doubt that obstructs the correct stage?
Because of this doubt, one does not realize the correct stage and does not attain the bodhisattva's stage of wisdom in the Great Vehicle. This is called the doubt that obstructs the correct stage.
Good son!
What is wrong grasping?
Wrong grasping refers to practicing giving and other practices in pursuit of karmic rewards, giving rise to the thought:
I cultivate such practices as giving and upholding precepts to attain the superior karmic rewards of gods and humans.
All such wrong pursuits are called wrong grasping.
Good son!
What is arrogance?
Giving rise to a mind of superiority and inferiority is called arrogance.
Thinking They are inferior to me, I am superior to them, such a mind of superiority and inferiority, winning and losing, is called arrogance.
Good son!
What is agitation?
Agitation is of two kinds:
The first is that which can give rise to afflictions, and the second is that which agitates and gives rise to afflictions.
Deluded thoughts and discriminations see form as pure, and for this reason, the activities of body, speech, and mind are all inverted, and therefore they are reprimanded by the sages.
What is agitation?
Agitation means that in the path to transcendence, the mind does not abide, and this is called agitation.
Good sons!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into ten kinds of dharma practices, knowing the dharmas that are opposed to emptiness.
Good sons!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into ten kinds of dharma practices, knowing those who are able to expound emptiness.
What are the ten?

Namely, those who are indestructible, unperturbed, neither greedy nor averse, neither practicing nor not practicing, neither disputing nor competing, neither increasing nor decreasing, who can patiently accept hearing that the nature of all conditioned phenomena is quiescent, who are neither startled nor frightened upon hearing that not a single dharma is produced by ordinary beings and not a single dharma is extinguished by buddhas, who do not give rise to doubt upon hearing that the nature of the world and the nature of nirvÄá¹‡a are equally non-arisen, who, upon hearing that the buddhas and tathÄgatas have an inexhaustible dharma body of wondrous bliss, correctly believe and enter.
Good sons!
What is meant by the indestructible one who can expound emptiness?
Good sons!
The one who can expound emptiness cannot be destroyed by worldly dharmas.
Why is this?
Because the mind does not rely on the eight worldly dharmas.
What are the eight?

They do not rely on gain, loss, and other matters, do not give rise to sorrow or joy, praise or blame, and have no delight or distress, nor do they have the two dharmas of blame and praise. Their minds are neither exalted nor low, and they are neither greedy for nor averse to suffering and happiness.
Thus, worldly dharmas cannot destroy them, and therefore they are called 'those who can speak of emptiness without being destroyed.'
Good man!
This is called 'the bodhisattvas who can speak of emptiness without being destroyed.'
Good man!
How is it called 'those who can speak of emptiness without being disturbed'?
Good man!
Those who can speak of emptiness do not grasp at dharmas and do not abandon dharmas.
What dharmas do they neither grasp nor abandon?
They know that these dharmas are empty and see that these dharmas are empty.
If one can thus neither grasp nor abandon, it is called 'those who can speak of emptiness without disturbing the mind.'
Good man!
How is it called 'those who can speak of emptiness without being greedy or averse'?
Good man!
One who can speak of emptiness has no dharmas to be greedy for and no dharmas to be averse to.
What dharmas are they not greedy for and not averse to?
One should know that these dharmas are empty and see that these dharmas are empty.
If one gives rise to greed and aversion towards dharmas, such a bodhisattva is not said to know emptiness and is not said to see emptiness.
If one is able to have a mind without greed and aversion towards dharmas, this is called not being greedy, not being averse, and being able to speak of emptiness.
Good man!
What is meant by being neither practicing nor not practicing and being able to speak of emptiness?
Good man!
One who can speak of emptiness neither practices dharmas nor does not practice dharmas.
With regard to what dharmas does one who can speak of emptiness neither practice nor not practice?
One should know that these dharmas are empty and see that these dharmas are empty, but one does not not practice the factors of enlightenment.
If one is able to know emptiness and see emptiness in this way, this is called a bodhisattva who neither practices nor does not practice and is able to speak of emptiness.
Good sons!
What is meant by one who can speak of emptiness without dispute or contention?
Good sons!
If one who speaks of emptiness has disputes or contentions with sentient beings, then they do not understand emptiness or see emptiness.
Because this bodhisattva knows and sees emptiness in disputes and contentions, there is no dispute or contention. This is called one who can speak of emptiness without dispute or contention.
Good sons!
What is meant by one who can speak of emptiness without increase or decrease?
Good sons!

One who can speak of emptiness does not know of the increase of a single dharma, nor does he know of the decrease of a single dharma, does not see the increase of a single dharma, nor does he see the decrease of a single dharma.
If one sees the increase or decrease of dharmas, then such a bodhisattva does not know emptiness or see emptiness.
If one can know emptiness and see emptiness, then one does not see the increase or decrease of dharmas. This is called one who can speak of emptiness without increase or decrease.
Good sons!
How can one hear the teaching that the nature of all conditioned activities is quiescent extinction and their mind is patient and able to speak of emptiness?
Good man!

One who can speak of emptiness does not see a single dharma arising, does not see a single dharma ceasing, this is called hearing the teaching that the nature of all conditioned activities is quiescent extinction and their mind is patient and able to speak of emptiness.
Good man!

How can one hear that ordinary beings do not give rise to a single dharma and the buddhas and tathÄgatas do not extinguish a single dharma, and not be startled or frightened, and be able to speak of emptiness?
Good man!
One who can speak of emptiness does not give rise to this thought:
'This is an ordinary being, this is a buddha.'
They know that the characteristics of buddhas and tathÄgatas and ordinary beings are equal.
If they see that the dharmas of ordinary beings are inferior and the buddha-dharmas are superior, such a bodhisattva does not know or see emptiness.

If one hears that ordinary beings do not give rise to a single dharma, this is the emptiness of ordinary beings; if one hears that buddhas do not extinguish a single dharma, this is the emptiness of buddhas. Thus, hearing it said that ordinary beings do not give rise to a single dharma and buddhas and tathÄgatas do not extinguish a single dharma, without alarm or fear, this is called not seeing a single dharma arising and not seeing a single dharma ceasing, and is able to expound emptiness.
Good son!
How does one know that the nature of the world and the nature of nirvÄá¹‡a are equally non-arising, not giving rise to doubt, and knowing one who is able to expound emptiness?
Good son!ğŸ”½If one sees that apart from the nature of the world there is the nature of nirvÄá¹‡a, such a bodhisattva does not know or see emptiness.
If one sees that the true nature of the world and the true nature of nirvÄá¹‡a are only of one characteristic, namely the nature of the unconditioned,

If one sees that the true nature of the world and the true nature of nirvana are equal in appearance, without high or low, and does not give rise to doubt, is not startled or frightened, this is called knowing the equality of the two dharmas of the nature of the world and the nature of nirvana, and is able to expound emptiness.
Good son!

How is it that hearing the teaching of the buddhas and tathÄgatas' eternally blissful wondrous body, inexhaustible dharma body, and being able to expound emptiness with right faith and right understanding?
Good son!
If one gives rise to this thought:
'The buddhas and tathÄgatas are bodies that are exhausted and extinguished.'
Such a bodhisattva does not know or see emptiness.
Why is it so?
The body of the buddhas and tathÄgatas is a body of true suchness and emptiness, not a body of adventitious afflictions and secondary afflictions.
This is called hearing the teaching of the tathÄgatas' eternally blissful wondrous body, inexhaustible dharma body, and being able to expound emptiness.
Good son!

This is called the bodhisattva's correct faith and understanding of the eternal, blissful, and wondrous body of all buddhas and tathÄgatas, and the inexhaustible Dharma body, of the one who can speak of emptiness.
Good sons!
